lines.text: After all, what am I? Just the greatest actor in the world.
I say, Digges, you don't suppose I've aroused her slap-me-again-I-love-it complex?
What are manners? Little rules for little people!

[about Basil]
I don't think there are words to describe him, do you?
Well, there probably are, but one would have to have a very extensive vocabulary.
This is Miss Kane.
I know you, you wear blue polka-dot shorts!
Are there no reformatories in California?
This Aunt Ella Paisley!

[Grabbing his hand]
Oh, Mr. Underwood! That hand! That Hand! That love line, and that mound of Venus. You'll be married once. Heaven help the poor girl, the lucky thing.
You're going to have love for breakfast, love for luncheon and love for dinner. Sweet, sugary, sticky worship. You're going to have a steady diet of it till you're ready to scream - you billygoat!
Aunt Ella, when Basil Underwood feels like a kipper, I'm sure he doesn't feel like an egg - even an aristocratic one.
Have you seen a mad woman 'round here?
Which one sir?

[to Basil]
Will you shut up?
What?
You meddlesome old nuisance, who asked you to interfere with our affairs, anyway?
She's absolutely right!
Well, I like that! Why, you - you...

You leave Henry out of this! If he'd had any sense he'd have realized I'd have forgotten all about you in two weeks. I was in love with Clark Gable last year, and if I can get over him, it's a cinch I can get over you.
Who's Clark Gable?

[to Henry]
He doesn't know who Clark Gable is.
Hmmm. I do.
Alright Joyce, I'm reaching for my gun.
Wait, I believe the trigger's at the rear end.
If you knew what I was thinking, you'd shrivel where you stand.
Oh, Mr. Actor Man! Where're you going?
To someplace where there are no dear little children
I'm Mrs. Kane, my friends call me Sugar.
How sweet of them.
I know something you don't know, I know something you don't know.
She knows something we don't know.
It can't be very important or we'd know it.

[Regarding the aviary]
If I weren't a gentleman's gentlemen I could be such a cad's cad!
[Birds loudly chirp]
Shut up!

As you leave the theatre this evening, that distasteful blotch you will see to the left of the stage door will be all that remains of our ex-doorman! And I wish I could do the same for you, you billy-goat!
I think I'm going to scream!
Now, Joyce...
I'm sure I'm going to scream! Ahhhh!
Now Joyce remember your glands!
You leave my glands out of this!
You thing! You unutterable!
What right has she to talk that way to me?
Practically none. Wives have so few rights nowadays.
Your wife?
Yes, my wife...
[looking at Joyce]
... wonderful.
We'll be married tomorrow!
Not to me you won't! Not tomorrow or tomorrow, or tomorrow!

I hope they don't ask for balloons! Actors coming here! You know William, if Mr. West had had to work for the money he's spending, this could never have happened! It's a clear case of money being left to the wrong...
It's time for breakfast.
Very well, but be ready for anything!
Wouldn't eggs do? We get them from very aristocratic hens!
Oh, Madeleine. I don't understand how a man I'm so crazy about can take such a delight in tormenting me!
Joyce, I'm a despirate man. If you don't open this door I'll kill myself.
Good! Let's have blood and destruction!
